conclusion: To determine the ratio of the magnitudes of the accelerations for particles A and B during their deceleration phases, we need to analyze the given velocity-time (v-t) graph and extract the relevant information.
For particle A: The deceleration phase occurs between t = t_0 and t = 3t_0.
For particle B: The deceleration phase occurs between t = 5t_0 and t = 6t_0.
Initial velocity (v_0) for particle A at t = t_0 is 2v_0.
Final velocity (v_f) for particle A at t = 3t_0 is v_0.

premise: Initial velocity for particle A is 2v_0, final velocity is v_0.
conclusion: The change in velocity (Δv) for particle A is Δv_A = v_0 - 2v_0 = -v_0.

premise: Deceleration phase for particle A is between t = t_0 and t = 3t_0.
conclusion: The time taken (Δt) for deceleration for particle A is Δt_A = 3t_0 - t_0 = 2t_0.
The acceleration a_A for particle A is a_A = -v_0 / 2t_0.
The magnitude of the acceleration for particle A is |a_A| = v_0 / 2t_0.
Initial velocity (v_0) for particle B at t = 5t_0 is v_0.
Final velocity (v_f) for particle B at t = 6t_0 is 0.

premise: Initial velocity for particle B is v_0, final velocity is 0.
conclusion: The change in velocity (Δv) for particle B is Δv_B = 0 - v_0 = -v_0.

premise: Deceleration phase for particle B is between t = 5t_0 and t = 6t_0.
conclusion: The time taken (Δt) for deceleration for particle B is Δt_B = 6t_0 - 5t_0 = t_0.
The acceleration a_B for particle B is a_B = -v_0 / t_0.
